properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A general 10 to 15 cm snowfall on tap tonight. An Alberta clipper type weather system has spread a large area of snow across parts of Northeastern Ontario. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are expected in most areas by the time the snow tapers off to a few flurries by Friday morning. Local amounts in the 15 to 20 cm range, such as at St. Joseph Island and possibly in one or two other localities north of Lake Huron are likely. Motorists should expect poor winter driving conditions and allow extra time to reach their destination. Visibility may occasionally be reduced to a few hundred metres in brief bursts of heavier snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-13T12:59:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-13T03:28:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1820583362.2019
Area: Sault Ste. Marie - St. Joseph Island, Greater Sudbury and vicinity, Elliot Lake - Ranger Lake, West Nipissing - French River, North Bay - Powassan - Mattawa, Blind River - Thessalon, Espanola - Killarney, Manitoulin Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall and strong winds are expected. Total rainfall: 20 to 40 mm. Higher amounts possible over the Long Range Mountains. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h, except locally 110 in areas prone to enhanced southeasterlies. Locations: western Newfoundland. Time span: Saturday evening until Sunday morning. Remarks: After a brief period of snow or freezing rain Saturday evening, rain at times heavy will follow for the remaining of the night until tapering to showers Sunday morning. Strong southeasterly winds and very mild temperatures will accompany the rain, leading to significant snow melt and run off. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-14T00:17:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-13T08:18:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1417804040.2019
Area: Corner Brook and vicinity, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Gros Morne, Bay St. George, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

Time span: Saturday evening until Sunday evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall and strong winds are expected. Total rainfall: 60 to 100 mm. Highest amounts inland. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h, except 120 in the Wreckhouse area. Locations: southwestern Newfoundland. Time span: Saturday evening until Sunday evening. Remarks: Rain will be heavy at times, and will occur in conjunction with very mild temperatures. Any existing snow cover will melt quickly and contribute to an elevated risk of flooding, especially near rivers or creeks and in low lying areas. Strong southeasterly winds will also develop with the arrival of the rain on Saturday evening and shift to strong southwesterly on Sunday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-14T00:18:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-13T08:19:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1730646442.2019
Area: Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of very cold wind chills is expected. A cold arctic airmass will bring extreme wind chill values of -45 degrees and colder to areas of northern Manitoba tonight. Although there will be moderation of extreme windchill values during the day, extreme windchill values in the -45 to -50 degree range will continue overnight for the next several days. Extreme cold warnings will likely be extended east and south over the coming days. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info Santé at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-13T13:15:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-12T21:16:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4006254159.2019
Area: Brochet, Tadoule Lake, Lynn Lake, Leaf Rapids, Pukatawagan, South Indian Lake and Amisk Prov. Park, Split Lake and York Landing, Thompson Thicket Portage and Pikwitonei, Nelson House

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A frontal system is slowly moving across the BC Interior. Snow associated with this system will re-intensify this evening. Additional 5 cm of snow is expected near Tumbler Ridge tonight. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-13T14:24:50-00:00

properties.Summary:

Time frame: Saturday morning through Saturday night. Remarks: Rain will spread across the region during the day Saturday and become heavy, at times, along with strong southerly winds. The rain is expected taper to showers early Sunday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall through the weekend Between 15 and 30 centimetres of snow are expected from Saturday to Sunday. A low pressure system from the Southern United States will intensify before reaching the province of Quebec on Saturday. An area of heavy snow will develop north of track. Quickly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Consider modifying any non essential travel plans. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-13T20:00:16-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A general 10 to 15 cm snowfall on tap into tonight. An Alberta clipper type of weather system has spread a large area of snow across parts of Northeastern Ontario. As of 6.00 PM, 15 cm of snow was reported at St. Joseph Island and 11 cm of snow was reported at Sault Ste. Marie airport. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are expected in most areas by the time the snow tapers off to a few flurries by Friday morning. Local amounts in the 15 to 20 cm range, such as at St. Joseph Island and possibly in one or two other localities north of Lake Huron are likely. Motorists should expect poor winter driving conditions and allow extra time to reach their destination. Visibility may occasionally be reduced to a few hundred metres in brief bursts of heavier snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-13T12:59:41-00:00

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain giving accumulations of 2 to 4 millimetres of freezing precipitation is expected on Friday night. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Northeasterly winds with gusts to 90 km/h are forecast to continue at Grise Fiord. Winds are expected to decrease slightly overnight before increasing again Friday afternoon. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-13T20:32:47-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills continues. A cold arctic airmass is expected to remain in place throughout the week. Wind chills will moderate during the day, before falling into the minus 40 to 45 range during the overnight to early morning periods. In the High Level and Fort McMurray regions, wind chill values are forecast to reach the -40 to -45 range, although cloud cover to the south and west of those communities should help keep temperatures warmer and the wind chill above -40. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-13T20:34:27-00:00

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Snow squalls are possible overnight. Total snowfall: 5 cm except 10 in the heaviest flurries. Maximum wind gusts: 50 to 70 km/h. Locations: western Cape Breton and the Highlands. Time span: overnight into early tomorrow morning. Remarks: Flurries at times heavy, with an enhanced risk of snow squall activity are expected as cold northwesterly winds prevail. In this case the blowing snow may be the main issue, resulting in poor visibility at times. Conditions will improve early Friday morning. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-13T10:59:15-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-13T02:18:15-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0915824165.2019
Area: Inverness County - Mabou and north, Victoria County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A bitterly cold Arctic air mass is keeping a firm frigid grip on far Northern Ontario. Extreme cold wind chill values near minus 45 will develop over portions of the area again tonight into Friday morning. After some moderation on Friday, the extreme cold wind chills near minus 45 may return again Friday night. ### Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 20 cm continues. Snow over the southern highway passes will re-intensify this evening. For the Coquihalla Highway from Hope to Merritt and Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass, additional 5 - 10 cm of snow can be expected tonight. The heavy snow will ease in intensity early Friday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rain, freezing rain, snow and wind likely this weekend. Total snowfall: 5 to 15 cm over northernmost regions. Total rainfall: 20 to 40 mm. Higher amounts possible along the Fundy coast. Maximum wind gusts: easterly becoming southerly with gusts between 50 to 80 km/h. Locations: New Brunswick. Time span: Saturday morning through Saturday night. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin early Saturday over northern regions, and then transition through freezing precipitation before changing to rain towards evening. Over central regions, some freezing rain is likely in the morning as temperatures slowly climb above the freezing mark. Over southern regions, rain will prevail for most of the day as southerly winds quickly push temperatures well above the freezing mark. These strong winds will produce the highest gusts along coastal areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-13T18:20:05-00:00
